txt.en: 'Please hurry, [placeholder], and fetch the healer! She can be found on the other end of the village. Hurry!'
Gather dishes from the hutch
The hutch is in the corner.\n\nYou should gather dishes from the hutch, and set the table.
You should set the table for Limril
Set the table for six ([placeholder]/[placeholder])
Limril is in her home in Dínadab in northern Lamedon.\n\nYou should offer to help Limril with dinner while she waits for Fuirion.
The table is in Gladion and Limril's home.\n\nYou should gather dishes from the hutch, and set the table.
Limril is in her home in Dínadab in northern Lamedon.\n\nYou should see what else Limril needs.
Talk to Limril
'Thank you for the help, [placeholder]. But where are Gladion and Fuirion? Really, now they are dreadfully late.'
Find out what the commotion is all about
The peace is broken by the sound of the door banging open
'He stumbled to our doorstep from across the farm, limping. Help us! Someone help my brother!\n\n'Fuirion, what is wrong? Where are you hurt?'
Examine Fuirion
While waiting for Fuirion to arrive, Limril has asked you to help with dinner.
You should help by setting the table
Fuirion's blood begins to form a pool on the floor, and it is clear that he has sustained a deep slash-wound in his belly
Offer to help Limril with dinner while she waits for Fuirion to arrive
Gladion kneels at the door with his brother in his arms.\n\nYou should ask Gladion what happened to his brother Fuirion.

'You wish to help with dinner? That is very kind of you, [placeholder]! I do not wish to be an ungracious host, for you earned a rest after today.'

You insist that you are up to the task, and ask what can be done to help.

'If you insist, I will not refuse a generous offer. The hutch in the corner -- would you set the table, if you please?'
Fuirion is at Gladion's doorstep.\n\nYou should examine Fuirion.
Instance: A Hard-earned Meal
Limril is in her home in <VILLAGE TBD> in northern Lamedon.\n\nYou should offer to help Limril with dinner while she waits for Fuirion.
